Award.AwardTitle: SaTC-EDU: EAGER: Big Data and Security: Educating the Next-Generation Security Analysts

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The project develops a new curriculum to educate next-generation security analysis. The new curriculum attempts to integrate two very distinct areas, data analysis and security. In particular, new labs and projects in existing courses for security are redesigned to make students naturally exposed to learn big data processing techniques with real-world examples. For example, "large-scale malware analytics" will be provided in Information Security Lab (CS6265), and similarly "large-scale static and dynamic analysis" will be provided in "Software Analysis and Testing" (CS 6340) at Georgia Tech. To broaden our efforts, all materials and resources (e.g., new course materials, labs and related tools) will be shared as online training modules publicly available so that the educational communities can adopt the data-driven approach in their education. As a result, the number as well as the quality of security analysts can be vastly increased, and hence our government and industries can be much more effective in securing the cyberspace.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The newly developed curriculum for security analytics is challenging because it requires deep understanding and integration of two very distinct areas, namely data analysis and security. The team PI and co-PIs demonstrate the feasibility of new education methodologies that intensively rely on real-world data in training students for future security analysts. With extensive experiences in applying data analysis to security, both in their research and Ph.D. student trainings, our team identified a set of basic principles and effective techniques of applying data analysis to security, such as feature extraction and construction, alert reduction and correlation, etc. 

As part of this project, each PI demonstrated various security courses that attempt to integrate the data-oriented approach as one more modules of the course, and made the courses publicly available: "Introduction to Information Security" (https://www.udacity.com/course/intro-to-information-security--ud459), "Information Security Lab" (https://tc.gtisc.gatech.edu/cs6265/2018/), "Network Security" (http://www.antonakakis.org/network-security), and "Software Analysis and Testing" (https://www.cis.upenn.edu/~mhnaik/edu/sat/index.html). Many of these courses will be offered (and also under development for public releases) as massive open online courses (MOOC) that are freely available to the public. In addition, PIs and co-PIs will offer them as required courses for the Online Master's in Cybersecurity degree that Georgia Tech recently announced to offer from 2019 Spring, which helps us to continuously maintain and develop the course-related resources.
